Content: Seems very specific to me in the articles description, but very vague in some parts of the patent.  I feel like they researched til they found a unique white space use for blockchain and gave themselves a good bit of room.  http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-bool.html&r=3&f=G&l=50&co1=AND&d=PTXT&s1=blockchain&OS=blockchain&RS=blockchain

Content: Welcome to the world of Corporate Thought.

Author: Cryptofist#7504
Content: Indeed.

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content: There's your legal loophole.

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content: "Based on ethereum, not Blockchain.  Blockchain by definition should be immuteable and open source.  This patent only applies to Ethereum, a specific protocol that does not specifically cover all blockchain projects."

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content: There are a couple reasons.  My favorite I had a few weeks ago was "Cheaters can go fork themselves"

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content: Verifiable gameplay and mechanic turn of events in tournament play.

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content: RTS like Starcraft and Warcraft 2/3 are big tourney games in Korea and other places in the world.   Having a verifiable sequence of events would make players, viewers and sponsors know who REALLY wins ðŸ˜ƒ

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content: Being able to trade items for real world value instead of in game gold.
